questions.uddipok:
Summarize the following text.
The term 'diaspora' is used to refer to people who have left their homelands and settled in other parts of the world, either because they were forced to do so or because they wanted to leave on their own. The word is increasingly used for such people as a collective group or a community. The world has seen many diasporas but scholars have been studying the phenomenon with great interest only in recent decades. Among the great diasporas of history is that of the Jewish people, who were forced to leave their lands in ancient times. The movement of Aryans from Central Europe to the Indian sub-continent thousands of years ago is also noteworthy diaspora, although the causes of this diaspora is unclear. In twentieth century history, the Palestinian diaspora has attracted a lot of attention and been a cause of concern for world leaders because of the plight of Palestinians. There have been massive diasporas in Africa, too, over the centuries, either because of war or because of the ravages of nature. But the chief reason why the phenomenon of diaspora is attracting so much attention now is globalization

sub_questions.explanation: Diaspora represents the people who have left their homelands and settled in other parts of the world. The diasporas take shelter in foreign countries leaving their ancestral land, either because they are forced to leave their country or they leave willingly. Among the great diasporas of history, the Jewish Diaspora is highly remarkable. Again, the Aryans left their homeland, Central Europe, thousands of years ago, and settled in the Indian sub-continent. In twentieth century, the Palestinian Diaspora has drawn the attention of the world leaders because of the plight and miseries of the Palestinians. However, globalization has contributed much to the recent attention to diasporas.

Summarize the following poem:
Because I have seen Bengal’s face I will seek no more;
The world has not anything more beautiful to show me.
Waking up in darkness, gazing at the fig-tree, I behold
Dawn’s swallows roosting under huge umbrella–like leaves. I look around me
And discover a leafy dome-Jam, Kanthal,
Bat, Hijol and Aswatha trees–
All in a hush, shadowing clumps of cactus and zedoary bushes.
When long, long ago, Chand came in his honeycombed boat
To a blue Hijol, Bat and Tamal shade near the Champa, he too sighted
Bengal’s incomparable beauty. One day, alas. In the Ganguri,
on a raft, as the waning moon sank on the river’s sandbanks.

sub_questions.explanation: The poem depicts the beauty of Bengal. The poet says that as he perceives the nature of Bangladesh, he is never inclined to enjoy the rest of the world. His country is replete with natural bliss. Here, he enjoys watching the activities of natural objects. All trees lie in calm and peace. They spread shade all around. This beauty was observed by the ancient people, too. Even, the poet associates the beauty of Bangladesh with the sorrows of people.

questions.uddipok:
Read the text and fill in the gaps with the correct form of verla as per subject and context.
Today, we (a) ____ (be) a free nation. We (b) ____ (have) to take great pains in order to (c) ____ (achieve) freedom Our War of Liberation (d) ____ (take) place in 1971 when Pakistan army (e) ____ (start) their onslaught. People from all walk of life (f) ____ (come) forward and got (g) ____(involve) in the war directly or inderectly. Though the freedom fighters (h) ____ (be) not trained enough, they (i) ____ (fight) with great courage, Many a man (j)____(kill) in the battlefield. They (k) ____ (not flee) from the battlefield (l) ____ (show) their backs, Rather, all of them (m) ____ (contribute) much to (n) _____ (achieve) independence.

sub_questions.explanation:
(a) are → Present tense, as we are currently a free nation.
(b) had → Past tense, as the struggle for freedom happened in the past.
(c) achieve → Base form after "to" (infinitive).
(d) took → Simple past, as the event occurred in 1971.
(e) started → Simple past, as it refers to the beginning of the attack.
(f) came → Simple past, as people joined the war in 1971.
(g) involved → Past participle, as it follows "got."
(h) were → Past tense, describing the freedom fighters.
(i) fought → Simple past, as the war happened in 1971.
(j) was killed → "Many a man" is singular, so singular verb "was" is used.
(k) did not flee → Negative past simple.
(l) showing → Present participle (-ing form) to describe the manner.
(m) contributed → Past simple, as it describes their role in the past.
(n) achieving → Gerund (-ing form) as the object of "to."

questions.uddipok: Write a composition on adulteration of foodstuff with clear references to the causes and consequences.

sub_questions.explanation:
Adulteration of Foodstuff: Causes and Consequences
Adulteration of foodstuff refers to the practice of intentionally adding harmful, low-quality, or synthetic substances to food items in order to increase profits. It is a serious issue that affects public health and undermines consumer trust. Adulterated food is often cheaper to produce but can pose significant health risks to those who consume it unknowingly.
Causes of Food Adulteration
One of the primary causes of food adulteration is the economic motive behind it. Sellers and manufacturers may use adulterants to increase the quantity or shelf life of food products, thereby reducing costs. For example, low-quality or artificial substances are often added to increase the weight of spices, grains, or beverages. This is especially common in the case of products like milk, tea, sugar, and edible oils.
The lack of stringent regulations and enforcement also contributes to the prevalence of food adulteration. In many countries, food safety laws are not strictly implemented, allowing unscrupulous traders to exploit gaps in the system. In some cases, poor awareness among consumers about food safety and quality standards makes it easier for adulterated food to enter the market without detection.
Another significant cause is the greed of certain manufacturers and traders. In their quest for higher profits, they compromise on quality and safety. For instance, chemicals, artificial colorants, and preservatives are added to food items like fruits, vegetables, and sweets to make them look fresh and appealing, despite the potential health risks they pose.
Consequences of Food Adulteration
The consequences of food adulteration are severe and can have both short-term and long-term effects on health. Immediate reactions to consuming adulterated food can include food poisoning, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which can be particularly dangerous for children and the elderly.
Long-term consumption of adulterated food can lead to chronic health problems, such as liver and kidney damage, cancer, and reproductive issues. For instance, the addition of harmful chemicals like formalin in fish or milk can lead to severe health complications over time. The accumulation of toxic substances in the body can weaken the immune system, making individuals more susceptible to diseases.
In addition to health risks, food adulteration also leads to economic losses for consumers. People pay for food products that are often less nutritious or potentially harmful. This can cause financial strain, especially in lower-income communities where access to safe food is already limited.
Moreover, food adulteration damages the reputation of businesses and industries that rely on consumer trust. Once a brand is associated with adulterated food, it can lose its customers and face legal consequences, leading to long-term financial losses.
Conclusion
In conclusion, food adulteration is a harmful practice with far-reaching consequences. The causes are multifaceted, including economic motives, lack of regulation, and consumer ignorance. The effects on health and the economy are undeniable, making it imperative for governments to enforce strict food safety regulations and for consumers to remain vigilant. Only through collective efforts can we ensure that the food we consume is safe, nutritious, and free from harmful adulterants.

Read the beginning of the following story and complete it in your own way. Give a suitable title to the story:
There was a naughty cowboy who grazed his cows beside a forest. He used to make fun with people crying Tiger! Tiger!.........

sub_questions.explanation:
Once there was a cowboy. He used to graze cow in the field. There was a forest beside the field. There lived tigers in the forest. The boy was very naughty. He went to the filed to feed the cow. He used to pastime there alone. To make fan, the cowboy used to shout uttering tiger, tiger and the people of nearby locality would come to save him. Seeing them, the cowboy started laughing. The people understood his trick, become bored and went away.
By the way, the boy used to continue his work in the field. One day, when he was grazing the cows in the field, a tiger come truly. He became afraid and started shouting for help to save him life. The people thought that he was making fan again. They did not pay heed to him. Nobody came to save him. Everyone thought that he was making fan with them as usual. The tiger attack the cattle and killed the boy. The boy lost his life for telling lies; He realized at last that if a liar speaks truth, nobody believes it. We can understand from the story that nobody trusts a liar.

sub_questions.explanation:
Grasp All Lose All
There were two brothers in a village. One was Karim by name and the other was Bashir. Karim was elder brother of Bashir. They began to grow up gradually. Suddenly their father died. They fell in problem to some extent. Karim was cleverer than Bashir. On the other hand, Bashir was very simple and honest. Karim always made his brother do difficult works and himself did not do anything. They had two things. One was a cow and the other was a palm tree. One day the two brothers divided their properties. Karim cleverly took the back part of the cow and gave the front to his brother. In the same way, Karim himself took the top of the palm tree and gave the bottom to his brother. Karim began to enjoy the benefit of the properties. But Bashir was deprived of getting any advantage. Karim began to drink milk and juice, of the palm tree. One day a wise man in the village, advised Bashir to cut down the palm tree of his own portion and stop feeding the cow. Then the problem was solved.
